SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action regarding Independence High School's Growth Impacts and Mitigations
	 
	 
At the November 19, 2015, Board meeting (Board Item 8.03), the Board directed Administration to develop an impact study and mitigation plan. District administration developed a study and associated mitigation plan, and held a Town Hall Meeting that was attended by over 300 students, teachers, staff and administrators.  The Town Hall Meeting was an effective venue for individuals to voice their concerns and reactions to the mitigation plan, and Administration was able to incorporate additional mitigations into the plan being presented. A follow up Staff Meeting was held on January 25, attended by over 30 individuals, to present the updated plan and solicit feedback.
	 
The mitigation plan includes short term solutions that can be implemented immediately to alleviate impacts; it also includes long term solutions, some of which are contingent upon future bond funds. The impact study and mitigation plan is delineated in the attached presentation.

$11,221,000

Approve and allocate $11,146,000 funded as indicated above, for the K09 Serving Kitchen, Parking Lot Signage, New Gymnasium, Practice Baseball Infield, Batting Cages, Building J Modernization, Demolition of the Portable Classroom Building West of Building M at Independence High School as presented.

TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance, and Facilities
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Approve and Allocate Funds for Alternative Education Facility Upgrades for Pegasus High School and the Post Senior Program
	 
At the November 5, 2015, Board meeting (Board Item 5.01), the Board directed Administration to develop a recommendation to locate Pegasus High School and the Post Senior Program.
	 
Pegasus High School is currently located at the Independence High School campus, in the Building L complex.  Pegasus will be dislocated in 2016, to allow for DCP charter high school to occupy those facilities; Pegasus will be relocated temporarily to the Portable Village at the northwest corner of the Independence campus.  Building J is the former public library, which was vacated when the new Education Park Branch Library was constructed.  Building J can be modernized to accommodate Pegasus High School, and provide two extra classrooms.  Building J’s location offers convenient access to the west perimeter of the campus, yet allows for Pegasus students to take advantage of facilities and services at Independence (such as Child Nutrition Services).  Architectural, construction management and survey service contracts previously awarded for modernization of Building J (for Post Senior) were suspended in October 2015.  With approval and allocation of funds to Building J’s modernization for Pegasus, those service contracts would be reactivated.
	 
The Board also directed Administration to develop a recommendation on where the Post Senior Program currently housed at the Independence Adult Education Center could be permanently relocated.  Administration recommends the Post Senior Program be relocated to 830 North Capitol Avenue, in new facilities to be developed contingent upon future bond funding.  The proposed site is adjacent to light rail public transit, which would support Post Senior curriculum.  Moreover, adjacency to the District Office would offer convenient access to office, warehouse and shop work environments, further supporting Post Senior Program learning opportunities.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT: 
$6,485,000 for Independence Building J Modernization                                                  
Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency $4,637,931.20
Measure I Restoration of Pegasus Measure E Allocation $328,010.01
Measure I Alternative Education Allocation $1,519,058.79
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees:
Approve and allocate $6,485,000, funded as indicated above, for the Independence High School Building J Modernization Project.
Approve relocation of Post Senior Program to 830 North Capitol Avenue, contingent upon future bond funding.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action Regarding Authorization to Enter Into Negotiations for Proposition 39 Charter School Facilities/Land Agreement at Education Center Property
	 
	 
At previous public Board meetings, Administration has presented concepts and proposed action plans in connection with the potential use and development of all or portions of the District’s Education Center property at 830 Capitol Avenue. At the November 19 Regular Board Meeting, the Board approved Administration undertaking specific tasks in furtherance of the continued study of the potential development and/or redevelopment of the Education Center property, with quarterly progress updates to the Board and provided that no bond funds are spent in performing the tasks.  
	 
Also at the November 19 Board meeting, Administration presented for Board consideration a proposed lease agreement with KIPP Bay Area Schools for the provision of Proposition 39 Charter School Facilities at the Independence High School site.  The Board did not take any action on the proposed agreement at that time and directed Administration to review and consider the intensity of use of the Independence campus facilities and the impact and potential impacts to students and staff and the District’s education program of shared use of the Independence facilities with charter schools.
	 
Administration met with Independence High School staff, students and community members and other stakeholders on January 25, 2016, to receive input and concerns regarding the use of the Independence facility and long-term needs and planning for that site.  
	 
In light of the issues and concerns raised, Administration is considering long and short-term strategies and opportunities to reduce the intensity of use at the Independence High School site to increase availability of the facilities resources for use by Independence students and staff and to enhance the overall campus atmosphere.  
	 
The Administration proposes to enter into discussions and negotiations with KIPP San Jose Collegiate charter school for a Proposition 39 lease agreement for a portion of the Education Center property for the construction of public high school facilities to relocate the KIPP charter school from the Independence High School site, and to enter into discussions with the County of Santa Clara and other responsible public agencies for the possible development of a portion of the public lands adjacent to the Education Center property to accommodate and support physical education activities and school-related athletic activities.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To Be Determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board authorize and approve the following:
	 
Authorize Superintendent or his designee(s) to enter into discussions and negotiations with KIPP San Jose Collegiate charter school for a Proposition 39 ground lease agreement for a portion of the Education Center property for the construction of public charter high school facilities by KIPP to relocate the KIPP charter school from the Independence High School site to the Education Center property; and
		 
Authorize Superintendent or his designee(s) to enter into discussions with the County of Santa Clara and other responsible public agencies for the possible development of a portion of the public lands adjacent to the Education Center property to accommodate and support physical education activities and school-related athletic activities.

SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Determine that Design-Build Delivery for the W.C. Overfelt High School Music, Art and Administration Building and Central Quad Modernization Project will Reduce Project Costs, Expedite the Project’s Completion, or Provide Features Not Achievable Through the Design-Bid-Build Process
		 
		 
On September 17, 2015, the Board of Trustees approved the W.C. Overfelt High School Music, Art and Administration Building and Central Quad Modernization Project, to be funded by Measure E Board/Cabinet Contingency funds (Item 15.01). On February 14, 2013, the Board considered public works construction project delivery methods available for this project, including design-bid-build, design-build, energy service contracting, and lease lease-back.  
		 
For this project, District staff has examined possible construction delivery methods and has concluded that the use of design-build delivery for the project offers the following potential advantages to the District not available under a traditional design-bid-build delivery method:
		 
Simplified contracting and contract administration:  There is one contract with the design-build entity instead of separate contracts with an architect and a contractor.   This reduces administrative burden and associated costs.
Cost containment:  The design-build entity is under a contract to complete the project meeting the District’s stated requirements within the contract price.
Cost savings:  Innovative, cost-effective solutions meeting performance criteria can be achieved by collaboration between the designer and builder, adding construction practicality to design imagination.  The builder is involved in the design process from the beginning and can provide helpful insights on construction materials and methods that can make the design more efficient and less costly to construct, operate and maintain. 
Early cost definition:  Project costs are determined much sooner than with the traditional design-bid-build process.   The design-build method enables the District to determine the cost of the project upon award of the design-build contract instead of after Division of the State Architect approval and construction contract bidding.   This early cost knowledge allows the District to make informed decisions on detailed scope in order to ensure equity of outcomes among the school sites.
Reduced number of change orders and disputes:  Because the designer and builder are part of the same design-build entity, and the District is not the guarantor of the completeness and accuracy of the work of the architect/engineer, the District may avoid conflicts and disputes, and the corresponding costs of those conflicts and disputes that can arise between the architect/engineer and construction contractor.
Greater risk shifting and more efficient risk allocation:  The vesting of design and construction functions under one entity enables proper allocation of risk under the design-build contract, because the contractor’s involvement in constructability review and existing site condition surveys during preconstruction activities reduces or eliminates the need for redesign during the construction phase. 
Reduction in adversarial relationships:  The designer and builder are teamed together, working under a single contract.  This teaming can significantly reduce traditional conflicts and finger-pointing between designer and contractor, and eliminate the need for the District to referee disputes.
Time savings:  The design-build entity is allowed the freedom to explore time-saving construction methods or systems while meeting the District’s stated criteria.  Early coordination between the designer and builder can help prevent construction delays.   Additionally, by overlapping design and construction to some extent, design-build can deliver the project faster than the design-bid-build approach.  Any and all of these elements can accelerate delivery of the new Student Union and modernized Quad.
Alternative selection process: Design-build entities may be selected on the basis of factors other than price alone.  Design-build entities can assemble a team of architects, engineers, subcontractors and suppliers with whom they have had previous successful collaborations, and that reflect the goals and needs of the project.  The District can select the winning team based on not only price, but also other factors including technical expertise, life cycle cost over 15 years or more, skilled labor force availability, safety record, successful previous experience, project-specific plans and schedules, design, and other qualitative elements.
		 
Education Code §17250.20 stipulates that upon making a determination by the governing board that it is in the best interest of the District, the Board may enter into a design-build contract for both the design and construction of a school facility if that expenditure exceeds two million five hundred thousand dollars ($2,500,000) if, after evaluation of the traditional design, bid, and build process of school construction and of the design-build process in a public meeting, the governing board makes written findings that use of the design-build process on the specific project under consideration will accomplish one of the following objectives:  reduce comparable project costs, expedite the project's completion, or provide features not achievable through the traditional design-bid-build method.  The governing board also shall review the guidelines developed pursuant to Education Code §17250.40 (Attachment A) and shall adopt a resolution approving the use of a design-build contract pursuant to this chapter prior to entering into a design-build contract.
